Michigan TV stations replace ‘false’ attack ads on Gary Peters
Updated Dec 17, 2019; Posted Dec 17, 2019
Gary Peters
Sen. Gary Peters, D-MI, introduces U.S. Senator Debbie Stabenow after she
won her re-election campaign for U.S. Senate Tuesday night at the Michigan
Democratic election night party held at the Sound Board Theater inside
MotorCity Casino in Detroit, Nov. 5, 2018. (Tanya Moutzalias | MLive.com)
Tanya Moutzalias | MLive.comTanya Moutzalias | MLive.com
Facebook Share
Twitter Share
By Malachi Barrett | mbarret1@mlive.com
U.S. Sen. Gary Peters’ reelection campaign convinced Michigan television
stations to replace a statewide attack ad it said makes “unquestionably
false” claims about the freshman Democrat.
Better Future Michigan, a dark money political group ran by the former
campaign manager for Peters’ likely 2020 Republican opponent, spent
$300,000 on digital and television ads which began running on Dec. 12.
Legal counsel for Peters’ campaign argued the ads falsely claim Peters
supports “Medicare for All, which eliminates private health insurance,"
and the Green New Deal in a letter requesting TV stations to pull the ad
off the air.
Nexstar TV stations in Grand Rapids, Lansing and Marquette removed the
original ads over the weekend, according to the Peters’ campaign. Station
managers were unable to be reached for comment.
Tori Sachs, executive director for Better Future Michigan, said new
versions of the ads replace a statement claiming Peters supports
eliminating private health insurance with a line about Peters “siding with
radical liberals.” The new version of the ad began running Monday, Sachs
said.
Peters told MLive he supports a public option allowing people to buy into
Medicare and supported legislative efforts to reduce the age for people
eligible to receive Medicare from 65 to 50. Peters said people should have
the option to keep their private health insurance, and he does not support
the Medicare for All plan proposed by U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt.
“I also support adding Medicare as an option in the Affordable Care Act,”
Peters said. " They have a choice of a number of private insurance
companies that they can pick from, and I would support Medicare being an
option, but it would be up to the consumer to determine whether or not
they wanted to purchase Medicare for a private option."
Peters previously said he supports “aspects” of the Green New Deal, but
did not vote in favor of it when the resolution came to the Senate floor.
Peters faced criticism by protesters in Sunrise Movement for not
supporting the Green New Deal more strongly.
Peters told MLive he considers climate change an “existential issue."
The Peters campaign’s legal counsel said the core claim of the attack ad
"is objectively and unquestionably false,” in a letter to television
stations.
“Better Future Michigan either did not bother to check Senator Peters’
clear position or is intentionally using your station to lie to the voters
of Michigan," the campaign wrote, according to a press release. "Either
way, your station bears responsibility for the advertisement’s claims and
must immediately stop airing this false advertisement.”
Sachs denied the Peters campaign’s charge that the original ad misled
voters about Peters’ stance.
“We 100% stand by our ad and everyone agrees Gary Peters supports Medicare
for All,” Sachs said. “We’re doing to do our job to educate people that
4.9 million Michiganders would lose employer-provided health insurance.”
Sachs is also the executive director of Michigan Rising Action, another
nonprofit not required to disclose its donors. She said the organizations
will continue “educating voters about what Medicare for All means.”
“We’re just starting,” Sachs said.
Michigan Democratic Party spokesperson Alex Japko said Better Future
Michigan can’t be trusted to inform Michigan voters.
“The fact that this dark money group’s first-ever ad was taken down for
being blatantly false shows just how little credibility they have," Japko
said in a statement. "It’s embarrassing for them, and shows why
Michiganders can’t trust what they say.”
Sachs managed Republican John James’ unsuccessful 2018 campaign. James is
running alone on the GOP ticket to oppose Peters in 2020.
James filed to run as a Republican candidate last week. He already has the
endorsement of the Michigan Republican Party and Vice President Mike
Pence, who are eager to oust Peters and hold on to Republican control of
the Senate.
